case_name: Messrs. Nand Lal Raj Kishan v. Sales Tax Officer

facts.text: This is a writ petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is a writ petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The petitioners, Messrs. Nand Lal Raj Kishan, carry on a business of commission agents at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners, Messrs. Nand Lal Raj Kishan, carry on a business of companymission agents at Delhi and are liable to pay sales tax in respect of their business under the provisions of the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act, 1941, as in force in Delhi.

facts.text: Petitioners are liable to pay sales tax under the Bengal Finance Sales Tax Act, 1941, as in force in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners, Messrs. Nand Lal Raj Kishan, carry on a business of companymission agents at Delhi and are liable to pay sales tax in respect of their business under the provisions of the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act, 1941, as in force in Delhi.

facts.text: They filed returns for four quarters of 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: They filed returns for four quarters of 195455 and claimed exemption in respect of sales of certain goods to the registered dealers under the provi- sions of s. 5 2  a  ii  of the said Act.

facts.text: Claimed exemption in respect of sales to registered dealers under s.5(2)(a)(ii).

anchor.surface_text: They filed returns for four quarters of 195455 and claimed exemption in respect of sales of certain goods to the registered dealers under the provi- sions of s. 5 2  a  ii  of the said Act.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer disallowed exemption by order dated April 11, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated April 11, 1956, the Sales Tax Officer disallowed the exemption claimed by the petitioners mainly on the ground that the alleged sales were made to those registered dealers whose activities had gone underground.

facts.text: Disallowance on ground that sales were to registered dealers whose activities had gone underground.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated April 11, 1956, the Sales Tax Officer disallowed the exemption claimed by the petitioners mainly on the ground that the alleged sales were made to those registered dealers whose activities had gone underground.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer issued demand notice for Rs. 1,11,890-11-0.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales. Tax Officer issued a demand numberice for a sum of Rs. 1,11,890-11-0 on account of sales tax.

facts.text: Petitioners appealed to Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners then carried an appeal to the Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax, Delhi.

facts.text: Assistant Commissioner set aside STO order and remanded for fresh decision.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Commissioner set aside the order of the Sales Tax Officer and remanded the case for a fresh decision in the light of certain judgments given by the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, in a number of similar cases.

facts.text: Bengal Finance Sales Tax Act, 1941 amended by Act No. 17 of 1956, inserting s.8A, effective October 27, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act, 1941, was amended by the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax   Delhi Amendment  Act, 1956, being Act No. 17 of 1956. This amending Act which came into force on October 27, 1956, inserted a new section, which is s. 8A of the Act.

facts.text: On May 17, 1957, petitioners asked for fresh registration certificate as original lost in transit.

anchor.surface_text: On May 17, 1957, the petitioners asked for a fresh registration certificate on the ground that their original certificate had been lost in transit.

facts.text: Petitioners asked to add cigarettes, bidis and glass to registration certificate.

anchor.surface_text: They further asked for the addition of some more items of goods in the registration certificate, such as cigarettes, bidis and glass of all kinds.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer found petitioners frequently shifting places of business.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Sales Tax Officer made certain enquiries and found that the petitioners had been frequently shifting their places of business and the sales alleged to have been made by them to some registered dealers were number genuine, because those persons companyld number be traced at the addresses given.

facts.text: Sales to some registered dealers not genuine as persons could not be traced.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Sales Tax Officer made certain enquiries and found that the petitioners had been frequently shifting their places of business and the sales alleged to have been made by them to some registered dealers were number genuine, because those persons companyld number be traced at the addresses given.

facts.text: On July 13, 1957, notice issued to petitioners to show cause why security of Rs. 10,000 under s.8A.

anchor.surface_text: On July 13,1957, such a numberice was issued to the petitioners to show cause why they should number be asked to furnish a security of Rs. 10,000 in accordance with the provisions of s. 8A.

facts.text: Petitioners appeared before STO, stated not prepared to deposit security, filed written explanation.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners then appeared before the Sales Tax Officer and made a statement that they were number prepared to deposit any amount as security. They also filed a written explanation objecting to the demand of security.

facts.text: Commissioner considered explanation and STO report.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then referred to the Commissioner of Sales Tax who company- sidered the explanation of the petitioners and the report of the Sales Tax Officer.

facts.text: Commissioner found necessity for security due to reputation, sales to unscrupulous dealers, frequent changes in name/place, late submissions.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner expressed his finding in the following words In view of the reputation that the dealer enjoys in the market, namely, that he being a companymission agent has been engaged in the business of selling goods to other companymission agents, all sales being effected to unscrupulous registered dealers, frequent changes in the name and place of busines without giving specific details, late submission of information regarding the changes in the name and place of business, number-submission of returns for the year 1956-57 within the prescribed time, it appears neces- sary to demand security under section 8A of the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act, 1941 as in force in Delhi.

facts.text: Commissioner ordered security of Rs. 5,000 by December 15, 1957 on November 27, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, on November 27, 1957, he made an order directing the petitioners to furnish security either in cash or by two personal sureties for a Bum of Rs. 5,000 by December 15, 1957.

facts.text: Petitioners filed revision to Chief Commissioner of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Against the aforesaid order of the Commissioner the petitioners went in revision to the Chief Commissioner of Delhi.

facts.text: Chief Commissioner dismissed revision on April 15, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Commissioner heard Counsel for the petitioners and by his order dated April 15, 1958, dismissed the application in revision.

facts.text: Writ petition in Punjab High Court summarily dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners then filed a writ petition in the Punjab High Court which was summarily dismissed.

facts.text: Petitioners impugned Commissioner's order dated November 27, 1957 on ground s.8A invalid.

anchor.surface_text: On the present writ petition the petitioners have impugned the order of the Commissioner dated November 27, 1957 on the ground that s. 8A of the Act under which the order was passed is companystitutionally invalid.

facts.text: Petitioners challenged s.8A as giving undefined unlimited power to Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: They have challenged the validity of s. 8A on three grounds firstly, it is companytended that s. 8A gives an undefined, unlimited and unrestricted power to the Commissioner of Sales Tax secondly, it is companytended that numberlimit is fixed with regard to the amount of security which may be demanded under the section

facts.text: Court held s.8A does not give unlimited power, subject to necessity for proper realisation of tax.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that these grounds have any substance. Section 8A does number give unlimited or unrestricted power. to the Commissioner of Sales Tax. It states inter alia that the Commissioner may impose for reasons to be recorded in writing as a companydition of the issue of registration Certificate to a dealer, or of the companytinuance of such a certificate, a requirement that the dealer shall give security up to an amount and in the manner approved by the Commissioner for the payment of the tax for which he may be or become liable under the Act this power of the Commissioner is, however, subject to the companydition that it must appear to him to be necessary so to do for the proper realisation of the tax levied under the Act.

facts.text: Opportunity was given to petitioners: notice issued, appeared, submitted explanation.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case such an opportunity was given to the petitioners. A numberice was issued to the petitioners by the Sales Tax Officer. The petitioners appeared before the Sales Tax Officer, submitted a written explanation and also made oral submissions.

facts.text: No violation of natural justice principles.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Chief Commissioner that there was numberviolation of the principles of natural justice in the present case.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 14, 1961 by K. DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 14. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is a writ petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioners non-submission of returns for 1956-57 within time.

anchor.surface_text: number-submission of returns for the year 1956-57 within the prescribed time
Petition Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fandamental Rights.
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is a writ petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.
under the provisions of the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act, 1941, as in force in Delhi.

concepts.unlisted_description: Sales tax legislation applicable in Delhi

anchor.surface_text: provisions of s. 5 2  a  ii  of the said Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Exemption for sales to registered dealers

anchor.surface_text: inserted a new section, which is s. 8A of the Act. This section reads as follows S. 8A. Security from certain class of dealers.The Commissioner, if it appears to him to be necessary so to do for the proper realisation of the tax levied under this Act, may impose for reasons to be recorded in writing as a condition of the issue of a registration certificate to a dealer or of the continuance, in effect, of such a certificate issued to any dealer, a requirement that the dealer shall give security up to an amount and in the manner approved by the Commissioner for the payment of the tax for which he may be or become liable under this Act.

concepts.interpretation: Power not unlimited; exercisable only when necessary for proper realisation of tax; reasons to be recorded; subject to revision.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners then filed a writ petition in the Punjab High Court which was summarily dismissed.

Section 8A does not give unlimited or unrestricted power. to the Commissioner of Sales Tax. It states inter alia that the Commissioner may impose for reasons to be recorded in writing as a condition of the issue of registration Certificate to a dealer, or of the continuance of such a certificate, a requirement that the dealer shall give security up to an amount and in the manner approved by the Commissioner for the payment of the tax for which he may be or become liable under the Act this power of the Commissioner is, however, subject to the condition that it must appear to him to be necessary so to do for the proper realisation of the tax levied under the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Discretionary power must be guided by statutory conditions like necessity for tax realisation; distinguished from cases with no guidance.

holdings.text: Section 8A does not give unlimited or unrestricted power to the Commissioner of Sales Tax as it is subject to the condition that it must appear necessary for the proper realisation of the tax levied under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that these grounds have any substance. Section 8A does number give unlimited or unrestricted power. to the Commissioner of Sales Tax. It states inter alia that the Commissioner may impose for reasons to be recorded in writing as a condition of the issue of registration Certificate to a dealer, or of the continuance of such a certificate, a requirement that the dealer shall give security up to an amount and in the manner approved by the Commissioner for the payment of the tax for which he may be or become liable under the Act this power of the Commissioner is, however, subject to the condition that it must appear to him to be necessary so to do for the proper realisation of the tax levied under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text requires reasons recorded and necessity for tax realisation; distinguishes from Dwarka Prasad where no guidance provided; follows Virendra and Kishan Chand.

holdings.text: The amount of security demanded under Section 8A is not unlimited as it must relate to the tax liability, nature of business, turnover, and is subject to revision by the Chief Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: As to the contention that there,is numberlimit to the amount which can be demanded as security, it is only necessary to point out that the amount that can be demanded as security must have relation to the payment of the tax for which the person concerned may be or become liable under the Act. The amount must depend on the nature of the business, its turnover and the amount of tax payable thereon by the person concerned. Furthermore, the order of the Commissioner under s. 8A is subject to revision by the Chief Commissioner and if an arbitrary or unreasonable amount is demanded, the order of the Commissioner will be subject to scrutiny by the Chief Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amount inherently limited by proportionality to tax payable and revisable; ensures not arbitrary.

holdings.text: Demanding security under Section 8A or similar provisions like Section 7(4)(a)(i) is neither arbitrary nor an unreasonable restriction on the right to carry on business.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 4a i of the Bengal Finance Sales Tax Act, 1941, gives the power to the Commissioner to demand reasonable security for the proper payment of tax payable under the Act. ... We approve of the view expressed therein that the power to levy a tax includes the power to impose reasonable safeguards in collecting it, and demanding security for the proper payment of the tax payable under the Act is neither an arbitrary nor an unreasonable restriction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax levy power includes reasonable collection safeguards; approves Calcutta High Court in Durga Prasad Khaitan.

holdings.text: Principles of natural justice apply to orders under Section 8A and were not violated in this case as petitioners were given notice, submitted explanation, and made oral submissions.

anchor.surface_text: As to the last contention that the section does number provide for any enquiry or any opportunity being given to the person against whom the order is proposed to be passed of being heard, this point was taken before the Chief Commissioner and the Chief Commissioner rightly pointed out that the principles of natural justice would apply and the person to whose prejudice the order is to be made must be given an opportunity to say whatever he has to say in his defence. In the present case such an opportunity was given to the petitioners. ... We agree with the Chief Commissioner that there was no violation of the principles of natural justice in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Natural justice satisfied by pre-order notice and hearing before STO; no second oral hearing before Commissioner required; no prior grievance raised.

holdings.text: The ratio decidendi in Dwarka Prasad does not apply to Section 8A as the latter provides statutory guidance unlike the absolute discretion there.

anchor.surface_text: That is number the position here. Section 8A itself gives the necessary guidance when it says that the Commissioner may exercise his power only when it is necessary to do so for the proper realisation of the tax levied under the Act. In a later decision of this Court in Virendra v. The State of Punjab it was pointed out that in Dwarka Prasads case the impugned provision prescribed number principles and gave number guidance in the matter of the exercise of the power, but in a case where the exercise of the power is conditioned by the statute itself, the ratio in Dwarka Prasad case does number apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Dwarka Prasad on basis of statutory conditions; follows Virendra and Kishan Chand.

precedents.citation: Messrs. Duarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Duarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 . That was a case in which under cl. 4 3  of the Uttar Pradesh Coal Control Order, 1953, the licensing authority was, given absolute power to grant or refuse to grant, renew or refuse to renew suspend, revoke, cancel or modify any licence under the Order.

precedents.case_name: Messrs. Duarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. The State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: absolute power to grant, refuse, renew, suspend, revoke, cancel or modify licence without guidance for discretion is invalid
precedents.cited_holding: there was nothing to regulate or guide the discretion of the licensing officer and the provision impugned therein committed to the unrestrained will of a single individual the power to grant, withhold or cancel licences in any way he chose

precedents.citation: Virendra v. The State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: Virendra v. The State of Punjab 1  it was pointed out that in Dwarka Prasads case 1  the impugned provision prescribed no principles and gave no guidance in the matter of the exercise of the power, but in a case where the exercise of the power is conditioned by the statute itself, the ratio in Dwarka Prasad case

precedents.case_name: Virendra v. The State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: where the exercise of the power is conditioned by the statute itself, the ratio in Dwarka Prasad case does not apply

precedents.citation: Kishan Chand Arora v. The Commissioner of Police, Calcutta 3

anchor.surface_text: Kishan Chand Arora v. The Commissioner of Police, Calcutta 3 . Section 7 4a i  of the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act, 1941, gives the power to the Commissioner to demand reasonable security for the proper payment of tax payable under the Act.

precedents.case_name: Kishan Chand Arora v. The Commissioner of Police, Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: the same view as in Virendra that Dwarka Prasad ratio does not apply when statute conditions the power

precedents.citation: Durga Prasad Khaitan v. Commercial Tax Officer 4

anchor.surface_text: Durga Prasad Khaitan v. Commercial Tax Officer 4  and it was held that the section did not confer unfettered or arbitrary power to the Commissioner. We approve of the view expressed therein that the power to levy a tax includes the power to impose reasonable safeguards in collecting it

precedents.case_name: Durga Prasad Khaitan v. Commercial Tax Officer
precedents.cited_proposition: section giving power to Commissioner to demand reasonable security for proper payment of tax does not confer unfettered or arbitrary power
precedents.cited_holding: the power to levy a tax includes the power to impose reasonable safeguards in collecting it, and demanding security for the proper payment of the tax payable under the Act is neither arbitrary nor an unreasonable restriction

h1 constrains the power under Section 8A by subjecting it to necessity condition

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that these grounds have any substance. Section 8A does number give unlimited or unrestricted power. to the Commissioner of Sales Tax. It states inter alia that the Commissioner may impose for reasons to be recorded in writing as a condition of the issue of registration Certificate to a dealer, or of the continuance of such a certificate, a requirement that the dealer shall give security up to an amount and in the manner approved by the Commissioner for the payment of the tax for which he may be or become liable under the Act this power of the Commissioner is, however, subject to the condition that it must appear to him to be necessary so to do for the proper realisation of the tax levied under the Act.
We do not think that these grounds have any substance. Section 8A does not give unlimited or unrestricted power. to the Commissioner of Sales Tax.

edges.explanation: h2 constrains the security demand under Section 8A by relating it to tax liability and allowing revision
h2 specializes h1 by detailing limits on security amount as part of the general power constraint
h2 states security amount under Section 8A is not unlimited, directly addressing i2

anchor.surface_text: As to the contention that there,is numberlimit to the amount which can be demanded as security, it is only necessary to point out that the amount that can be demanded as security must have relation to the payment of the tax for which the person concerned may be or become liable under the Act. The amount must depend on the nature of the business, its turnover and the amount of tax payable thereon by the person concerned. Furthermore, the order of the Commissioner under s. 8A is subject to revision by the Chief Commissioner and if an arbitrary or unreasonable amount is demanded, the order of the Commissioner will be subject to scrutiny by the Chief Commissioner.
We do not think that these grounds have any substance. Section 8A does not give unlimited or unrestricted power. to the Commissioner of Sales Tax.
cessary or obligatory. The petitioners had an opportunity of saying what they had to say against the demand of security. They raised their objections

edges.explanation: Holding explicitly concludes that demanding security under s.8A is not an unreasonable restriction on business, directly addressing the issue of whether s.8A imposes such restriction without enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 4a i of the Bengal Finance Sales Tax Act, 1941, gives the power to the Commissioner to demand reasonable security for the proper payment of tax payable under the Act. ... We approve of the view expressed therein that the power to levy a tax includes the power to impose reasonable safeguards in collecting it, and demanding security for the proper payment of the tax payable under the Act is neither an arbitrary nor an unreasonable restriction.
We do not think that these grounds have any substance. Section 8A does not give unlimited or unrestricted power. to the Commissioner of Sales Tax.

anchor.surface_text: As to the last contention that the section does number provide for any enquiry or any opportunity being given to the person against whom the order is proposed to be passed of being heard, this point was taken before the Chief Commissioner and the Chief Commissioner rightly pointed out that the principles of natural justice would apply and the person to whose prejudice the order is to be made must be given an opportunity to say whatever he has to say in his defence. In the present case such an opportunity was given to the petitioners. ... We agree with the Chief Commissioner that there was no violation of the principles of natural justice in the present case.
We do not think that these grounds have any substance. Section 8A does not give unlimited or unrestricted power. to the Commissioner of Sales Tax.
We do not think that these grounds have any substance. Section 8A does not give unlimited or unrestricted power. to the Commissioner of Sales Tax.
